Federated Learning under Heterogeneous and Correlated Client Availability

Angelo Rodio1, Francescomaria Faticanti1, Othmane Marfoq12, Giovanni Neglia1, Emilio Leonardi3 This research was supported by the French government through the 3IA Côte d’Azur Investments in the Future project by the National Research Agency (ANR) with reference ANR-19-P3IA-0002, and by Groupe La Poste, sponsor of Inria Foundation, in the framework of FedMalin Inria Challenge.A first version of this work has been accepted at IEEE INFOCOM 2023. 1Inria, Université Côte d’Azur, France. Email: {firstname.lastname}@inria.fr,
2Accenture Labs, Sophia-Antipolis, France. Email: {firstname.lastname}@accenture.com,
3Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy. Email: {firstname.lastname}@polito.it
Abstract

The enormous amount of data produced by mobile and IoT devices has motivated the development of federated learning (FL), a framework allowing such devices (or clients) to collaboratively train machine learning models without sharing their local data. FL algorithms (like FedAvg) iteratively aggregate model updates computed by clients on their own datasets. Clients may exhibit different levels of participation, often correlated over time and with other clients. This paper presents the first convergence analysis for a FedAvg-like FL algorithm under heterogeneous and correlated client availability. Our analysis highlights how correlation adversely affects the algorithm’s convergence rate and how the aggregation strategy can alleviate this effect at the cost of steering training toward a biased model. Guided by the theoretical analysis, we propose CA-Fed, a new FL algorithm that tries to balance the conflicting goals of maximizing convergence speed and minimizing model bias. To this purpose, CA-Fed dynamically adapts the weight given to each client and may ignore clients with low availability and large correlation. Our experimental results show that CA-Fed achieves higher time-average accuracy and a lower standard deviation than state-of-the-art AdaFed and F3AST, both on synthetic and real datasets.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Distributed Optimization.

I Introduction

The enormous amount of data generated by mobile and IoT devices motivated the emergence of distributed machine learning training paradigms [1, 2]. Federated Learning (FL) [3, 4, 5, 6] is an emerging framework where geographically distributed devices (or clients) participate in the training of a shared Machine Learning (ML) model without sharing their local data. FL was proposed to reduce the overall cost of collecting a large amount of data as well as to protect potentially sensitive users’ private information. In the original Federated Averaging algorithm (FedAvg) [4], a central server selects a random subset of clients from the set of available clients and broadcasts them the shared model. The sampled clients perform a number of independent Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) steps over their local datasets and send their local model updates back to the server. Then, the server aggregates the received client updates to produce a new global model, and a new training round begins. At each iteration of FedAvg, the server typically samples randomly a few hundred devices to participate [7, 8].

In real-world scenarios, the availability/activity of clients is dictated by exogenous factors that are beyond the control of the orchestrating server and hard to predict. For instance, only smartphones that are idle, under charge, and connected to broadband networks are commonly allowed to participate in the training process [4, 9]. These eligibility requirements can make the availability of devices correlated over time and space [7, 10, 11, 12]. For example, temporal correlation may origin from a smartphone being under charge for a few consecutive hours and then ineligible for the rest of the day. Similarly, the activity of a sensor powered by renewable energy may depend on natural phenomena intrinsically correlated over time (e.g., solar light). Spatial correlation refers instead to correlation across different clients, which often emerges as consequence of users’ different geographical distribution. For instance, clients in the same time zone often exhibit similar availability patterns, e.g., due to time-of-day effects.

Temporal correlation in the data sampling procedure is known to negatively affect the performance of ML training even in the centralized setting [13, 14] and can potentially lead to catastrophic forgetting: the data used during the final training phases can have a disproportionate effect on the final model, “erasing” the memory of previously learned information [15, 16]. Catastrophic forgetting has also been observed in FL, where clients in the same geographical area have more similar local data distributions and clients’ participation follows a cyclic daily pattern (leading to spatial correlation) [7, 10, 11, 17]. Despite this evidence, a theoretical study of the convergence of FL algorithms under both temporally and spatially correlated client participation is still missing.

This paper provides the first convergence analysis of FedAvg [4] under heterogeneous and correlated client availability. We assume that clients’ temporal and spatial availability follows an arbitrary finite-state Markov chain: this assumption models a realistic scenario in which the activity of clients is correlated and, at the same time, still allows the analytical tractability of the system. Our theoretical analysis (i) quantifies the negative effect of correlation on the algorithm’s convergence rate through an additional term, which depends on the spectral properties of the Markov chain; (ii) points out a trade-off between two conflicting objectives: slow convergence to the optimal model, or fast convergence to a biased model, i.e., a model that minimizes an objective function different from the initial target. Guided by insights from the theoretical analysis, we propose CA-Fed, an algorithm which dynamically assigns weights to clients and achieves a good trade-off between maximizing convergence speed and minimizing model bias. Interestingly, CA-Fed can decide to ignore clients with low availability and high temporal correlation. Our experimental results demonstrate that excluding such clients is a simple, but effective approach to handle the heterogeneous and correlated client availability in FL. Indeed, while CA-Fed achieves a comparable maximum accuracy as the state-of-the-art methods F3AST [18] and AdaFed [19], its test accuracy exhibits higher time-average and smaller variability over time.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the problem of correlated client availability in FL and discusses the main related works. Section III provides a convergence analysis of FedAvg under heterogeneous and correlated client participation. CA-Fed, our correlation-aware FL algorithm, is presented in Section IV. We evaluate CA-Fed in Section V, comparing it with state-of-the-art methods on synthetic and real-world data. Section VII concludes the paper.

II Background and Related Works

We consider a finite set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} of N𝑁N clients. Each client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} holds a local dataset Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. Problem (1) is commonly solved through iterative algorithms [4, 8] requiring multiple communication rounds between the server and the clients. At round t>0𝑡0t>0, the server broadcasts the latest estimate of the global model 𝒘t,0subscript𝒘𝑡0\bm{w}_{t,0} to the set of available clients (Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t}). The choice of the aggregation weights defines an aggregation strategy (we will discuss different aggregation strategies later). The aggregated update ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t} can be interpreted as a proxy for −∇F​(𝒘t,0)∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡0-\nabla F(\bm{w}_{t,0}); the server applies it to the global model:

𝒘t+1,0=𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣W​(𝒘t,0+ηs⋅Δt)subscript𝒘𝑡10subscript𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝑊subscript𝒘𝑡0⋅subscript𝜂𝑠subscriptΔ𝑡\displaystyle\textstyle\bm{w}_{t+1,0}=\mathbf{Proj}_{W}{(\bm{w}_{t,0}+\eta_{s}\cdot\Delta_{t})} (3)

where 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣W​(⋅)subscript𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝑊⋅\mathbf{Proj}_{W}{(\cdot)} denotes the projection over the set W𝑊W, and ηs>0subscript𝜂𝑠0\eta_{s}>0 is an appropriately chosen learning rate, referred to as the server learning rate.111 The aggregation rule (3) has been considered also in other works, e.g., [20, 21, 8]. In other FL algorithms, the server computes an average of clients’ local models. This aggregation rule can be obtained with minor changes to (3).

The aggregate update ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t} is, in general, a biased estimator of −∇F​(𝒘t,0)∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡0{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}-}\nabla F(\bm{w}_{t,0}), where each client k𝑘k is taken into account proportionally to its frequency of appearance in the set Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t} and to its aggregation weight qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}. Indeed, under proper assumptions specified in Section III, one can show (see Theorem 2) that the update rule described by (2) and (3) converges to the unique minimizer of a biased global objective FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}, which depends both on the clients’ availability (i.e., on the sequence (At)t>0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0\left(A_{t}\right)_{t>0}) and on the aggregation strategy (i.e., on 𝒒=(qk)k∈𝒦𝒒subscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑘𝒦\bm{q}=\left(q_{k}\right)_{k\in\mathcal{K}}):

FB​(𝒘)≔∑k=1Npk​Fk​(𝒘),with​pk≔πk​qk∑h=1Nπh​qh,formulae-sequence≔subscript𝐹𝐵𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘≔withsubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝑁subscript𝜋ℎsubscript𝑞ℎ\displaystyle\textstyle F_{B}(\bm{w})\coloneqq\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}F_{k}(\bm{w}),~{}\text{with}~{}p_{k}\coloneqq\frac{\pi_{k}q_{k}}{\sum_{h=1}^{N}\pi_{h}q_{h}}, (4)

where πk≔limt→∞ℙ​(k∈At)≔subscript𝜋𝑘subscript→𝑡ℙ𝑘subscript𝐴𝑡\pi_{k}\coloneqq\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{P}(k\in A_{t}) is the asymptotic availability of client k𝑘k. The coefficients 𝒑=(pk)k∈𝒦𝒑subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑘𝒦\bm{p}=(p_{k})_{k\in\mathcal{K}} can be interpreted as the biased importance the server is giving to each client k𝑘k during training, in general different from the target importance 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha}. In what follows, 𝒘B∗superscriptsubscript𝒘𝐵\bm{w}_{B}^{*} (resp. FB∗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}^{*}) denotes the minimizer (resp. the minimum value) of FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}.

In some large-scale FL applications, like training Google keyboard next-word prediction models, each client participates in training at most for one round. The orchestrator usually selects a few hundred clients at each round for a few thousand rounds (e.g., see [5, Table 2]), but the available set of clients may include hundreds of millions of Android devices. In this scenario, it is difficult to address the potential bias unless there is some a-priori information about each client’s availability. Anyway, FL can be used by service providers with access to a much smaller set of clients (e.g., smartphone users that have installed a specific app). In this case, a client participates multiple times in training: the orchestrating server may keep track of each client’s availability and try to compensate for the potentially dangerous heterogeneity in their participation.

Much previous effort on federated learning [4, 22, 23, 24, 25, 17, 19, 18] considered this problem and, under different assumptions on the clients’ availability (i.e., on (At)t>0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0\left(A_{t}\right)_{t>0}), designed aggregation strategies that unbias ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t} through an appropriate choice of 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}. Reference [22] provides the first analysis of FedAvg on non-iid data under clients’ partial participation. Their analysis covers both the case when active clients are sampled uniformly at random without replacement from 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} and assigned aggregation weights equal to their target importance (as assumed in [4]), and the case when active clients are sampled iid with replacement from 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} with probabilities 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} and assigned equal weights (as assumed in [23]). However, references [4, 22, 23] ignore the variance induced by the clients stochastic availability. The authors of [24] reduce such variance by considering only the clients with important updates, as measured by the value of their norm. References [17] and [25] reduce the aggregation variance through clustered and soft-clustered sampling, respectively.

Some recent works [19, 18, 26] do not actively pursue the optimization of the unbiased objective. Instead, they derive bounds for the convergence error and propose heuristics to minimize those bounds, potentially introducing some bias. Our work follows a similar development: we compare our algorithm with F3AST from [18] and AdaFed from [19].

The novelty of our study is in considering the spatial and temporal correlation in clients’ availability dynamics. As discussed in the introduction, such correlations are also introduced by clients’ eligibility criteria, e.g., smartphones being under charge and connected to broadband networks. The effect of correlation has been ignored until now, probably due to the additional complexity in studying FL algorithms’ convergence. To the best of our knowledge, the only exception is [18], which scratches the issue of spatial correlation by proposing two different algorithms for the case when clients’ availabilities are uncorrelated and for the case when they are positively correlated (there is no smooth transition from one algorithm to the other as a function of the degree of correlation).

The effect of temporal correlation on centralized stochastic gradient methods has been addressed in [14, 13, 27, 12]: these works study a variant of stochastic gradient descent where samples are drawn according to a Markov chain. Reference [12] extends its analysis to a FL setting where each client draws samples according to a Markov chain. In contrast, our work does not assume a correlation in the data sampling but rather in the client’s availability. Nevertheless, some of our proof techniques are similar to those used in this line of work and, in particular, we rely on some results in [14].

III Analysis

III-A Main assumptions

We consider a time-slotted system where a slot corresponds to one FL communication round. We assume that clients’ availability over the timeslots t∈ℕ𝑡ℕt\in\mathbb{N} follows a discrete-time Markov chain (At)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0}.222 In Section III-D we will focus on the case where this chain is the superposition of N𝑁N independent Markov chains, one for each client.

Assumption 1.

The Markov chain (At)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0} on the finite state space [M]delimited-[]𝑀[M] is time-homogeneous, irreducible, and aperiodic. It has transition matrix 𝐏𝐏\bm{P} and stationary distribution 𝛑𝛑\bm{\pi}.

Markov chains have already been used in the literature to model the dynamics of stochastic networks where some nodes or edges in the graph can switch between active and inactive states [28, 29]. The previous Markovian assumption, while allowing a great degree of flexibility, still guarantees the analytical tractability of the system. The distance dynamics between current and stationary distribution of the Markov process can be characterized by the spectral properties of its transition matrix 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} [30]. Let λ2​(𝑷)subscript𝜆2𝑷\lambda_{2}(\bm{P}) denote the the second largest eigenvalue of 𝑷𝑷\bm{P} in absolute value. Previous works [14] have shown that:

maxi,j∈[M]⁡|[𝑷t]i,j−πj|≤CP⋅λ​(𝑷)t,subscript𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑀subscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝑷𝑡𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋𝑗⋅subscript𝐶𝑃𝜆superscript𝑷𝑡\displaystyle\textstyle\max\limits_{i,j\in[M]}{\lvert[\bm{P}^{t}]_{i,j}-\pi_{j}\rvert}\leq C_{P}\cdot\lambda(\bm{P})^{t}, for t≥TP,for t≥TP\displaystyle\text{for $t\geq T_{P}$}, (5)

where the parameter λ​(𝑷)≔(λ2​(𝑷)+1)/2≔𝜆𝑷subscript𝜆2𝑷12\lambda(\bm{P})\coloneqq{(\lambda_{2}(\bm{P})+1)}/{2}, and CP,TPsubscript𝐶𝑃subscript𝑇𝑃C_{P},T_{P} are positive constants whose values are reported in [14, Lemma 1].333Note that (5) holds for different definitions of λ​(𝑷)𝜆𝑷\lambda(\bm{P}) as far as λ​(𝑷)∈(λ2​(𝑷),1)𝜆𝑷subscript𝜆2𝑷1\lambda(\bm{P})\in(\lambda_{2}(\bm{P}),1). The specific choice for λ​(𝑷)𝜆𝑷\lambda(\bm{P}) changes the constants CPsubscript𝐶𝑃C_{P} and TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}. Note that λ​(𝑷)𝜆𝑷\lambda(\bm{P}) quantifies the correlation of the Markov process (At)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0}: the closer λ​(𝑷)𝜆𝑷\lambda(\bm{P}) is to one, the slower the Markov chain converges to its stationary distribution.

In our analysis, we make the following additional assumptions. Let 𝒘∗,𝒘B∗superscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝐵\bm{w}^{*},\bm{w}_{B}^{*} denote the minimizers of F𝐹F and FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B} on W𝑊W, respectively.

Assumption 2.

The hypothesis class W𝑊W is convex, compact, and contains in its interior the minimizers 𝐰∗,𝐰B∗,𝐰k∗superscript𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐰𝐵superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘\bm{w}^{*},\bm{w}_{B}^{*},\bm{w}_{k}^{*}.

The following assumptions concern clients’ local objective functions {Fk}k∈𝒦subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑘𝒦\{F_{k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}. Assumptions 3 and 4 are standard in the literature on convex optimization [31, Sections 4.1, 4.2]. Assumption 5 is a standard hypothesis in the analysis of federated optimization algorithms [8, Section 6.1].

Assumption 3 (L-smoothness).

The local functions {Fk}k=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑘1𝑁\{F_{k}\}_{k=1}^{N} have L-Lipschitz continuous gradients: Fk​(𝐯)≤Fk​(𝐰)+⟨∇Fk​(𝐰),𝐯−𝐰⟩+L2​∥𝐯−𝐰∥22subscript𝐹𝑘𝐯subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰𝐯𝐰𝐿2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐯𝐰22F_{k}(\bm{v})\leq F_{k}(\bm{w})+\langle\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}),\bm{v}-\bm{w}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\lVert\bm{v}-\bm{w}\right\rVert_{2}^{2}, ∀𝐯,𝐰∈Wfor-all𝐯𝐰𝑊\forall\bm{v},\bm{w}\in W.

Assumption 4 (Strong convexity).

The local functions {Fk}k=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑘1𝑁\{F_{k}\}_{k=1}^{N} are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex: Fk​(𝐯)≥Fk​(𝐰)+⟨∇Fk​(𝐰),𝐯−𝐰⟩+μ2​∥𝐯−𝐰∥22,∀𝐯,𝐰∈Wformulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑘𝐯subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰𝐯𝐰𝜇2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐯𝐰22for-all𝐯𝐰𝑊F_{k}(\bm{v})\geq F_{k}(\bm{w})+\langle\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}),\bm{v}-\bm{w}\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\bm{v}-\bm{w}\right\rVert_{2}^{2},~{}\forall\bm{v},\bm{w}\in W.

Assumption 5 (Bounded variance).

The variance of stochastic gradients in each device is bounded: 𝔼‖∇Fk​(𝐰t,jk,ξt,jk)−∇Fk​(𝐰t,jk)‖2≤σk2,k=1,…,Nformulae-sequence𝔼superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑗𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑗𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2𝑘1…𝑁\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\|\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}_{t,j}^{k},\xi_{t,j}^{k})-\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w}_{t,j}^{k})\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{k}^{2},~{}k=1,\dots,N.

Assumptions 2–5 imply the following properties for the local functions, described by Lemma 1 (proof in Appendix -B).

Lemma 1.

Under Assumptions 2–5, there exist constants D𝐷D, G𝐺G, and H>0𝐻0H>0, such that, for 𝐰∈W𝐰𝑊\bm{w}\in W and k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, we have:

‖∇Fk​(𝒘)‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘\displaystyle\|\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w})\| ≤D,absent𝐷\displaystyle\leq D, (6)
𝔼‖∇Fk​(𝒘,ξ)‖2𝔼superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘𝜉2\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\|\nabla F_{k}(\bm{w},\xi)\|^{2} ≤G2,absentsuperscript𝐺2\displaystyle\leq G^{2}, (7)
|Fk​(𝒘)−Fk​(𝒘B∗)|subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝐵\displaystyle\lvert F_{k}(\bm{w})-F_{k}(\bm{w}_{B}^{*})\rvert ≤H.absent𝐻\displaystyle\leq H. (8)

Similarly to other works [22, 23, 32, 8], we introduce a metric to quantify the heterogeneity of clients’ local datasets:

ΓΓ\displaystyle\Gamma ≔maxk∈𝒦⁡{Fk​(𝒘∗)−Fk∗}.≔absentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘\displaystyle\coloneqq\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{F_{k}(\bm{w}^{*})-F_{k}^{*}\}. (9)

If the local datasets are identical, the local functions {Fk}k∈𝒦subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑘𝒦\{F_{k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}} coincide among them and with F𝐹F, 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*} is a minimizer of each local function, and Γ=0Γ0\Gamma=0. In general, ΓΓ\Gamma is smaller the closer the distributions the local datasets are drawn from.

III-B Main theorems

Theorem 1 (proof in Appendix -A) decomposes the error of the target global objective as the sum of an optimization error for the biased global objective and a bias error.

Theorem 1 (Decomposing the total error).

Under Assumptions 2–4, the optimization error of the target global objective ϵ=F​(𝐰)−F∗italic-ϵ𝐹𝐰superscript𝐹\epsilon=F(\bm{w})-F^{*} can be bounded as follows:

ϵ≤2​κ2​(FB​(𝒘)−FB∗)⏟≔ϵopt+2​κ4​χ𝜶∥𝒑2​Γ⏟≔ϵbias,italic-ϵsubscript⏟2superscript𝜅2subscript𝐹𝐵𝒘superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵≔absentsubscriptitalic-ϵoptsubscript⏟2superscript𝜅4subscriptsuperscript𝜒2conditional𝜶𝒑Γ≔absentsubscriptitalic-ϵbias\displaystyle\epsilon\leq\underbrace{2\kappa^{2}(F_{B}(\bm{w})-F_{B}^{*})\vphantom{\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}}}}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{opt}}}+\underbrace{2\kappa^{4}\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}}\Gamma}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{bias}}}, (10)

where κ≔L/μ≔𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa\coloneqq{L}/{\mu}, and χ𝛂∥𝐩2≔∑k=1N(αk−pk)2/pk≔subscriptsuperscript𝜒2conditional𝛂𝐩superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘2subscript𝑝𝑘\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}}\coloneqq\sum_{k=1}^{N}{(\alpha_{k}-p_{k})^{2}}/{p_{k}}.

Theorem 2 below proves that the optimization error ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} associated to the biased objective FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}, evaluated on the trajectory determined by scheme (3), asymptotically vanishes. The non-vanishing bias error ϵbiassubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}} captures the discrepancy between F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}) and FB​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝐵𝒘F_{B}(\bm{w}). This latter term depends on the chi-square divergence χ𝜶∥𝒑2subscriptsuperscript𝜒2conditional𝜶𝒑\chi^{2}_{\bm{\alpha}\parallel\bm{p}} between the target and biased probability distributions 𝜶=(αk)k∈𝒦𝜶subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑘𝒦\bm{\alpha}=(\alpha_{k})_{k\in\mathcal{K}} and 𝒑=(pk)k∈𝒦𝒑subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑘𝒦\bm{p}=(p_{k})_{k\in\mathcal{K}}, and on ΓΓ\Gamma, that quantifies the degree of heterogeneity of the local functions. When all local functions are identical (Γ=0Γ0\Gamma=0), the bias term ϵbiassubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}} also vanishes. For Γ>0Γ0\Gamma>0, the bias error can still be controlled by the aggregation weights assigned to the devices. In particular, the bias term vanishes when qk∝αk/πk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦q_{k}\propto\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Since it asymptotically cancels the bias error, we refer to this choice as unbiased aggregation strategy.

However, in practice, FL training is limited to a finite number of iterations T𝑇T (typically a few hundreds [7, 5]), and the previous asymptotic considerations may not apply. In this regime, the unbiased aggregation strategy can be suboptimal, since the minimization of ϵbiassubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}} not necessarily leads to the minimization of the total error ϵ≤ϵopt+ϵbiasitalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{\text{opt}}+\epsilon_{\text{bias}}. This motivates the analysis of the optimization error ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}}.

Theorem 2 (Convergence of the optimization error ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt{\epsilon}_{\text{{opt}}}).

Let Assumptions 1–5 hold and the constants M,L,D,G,H,Γ𝑀𝐿𝐷𝐺𝐻ΓM,L,D,G,H,\Gamma, σk,CP,TP,λ​(𝐏)subscript𝜎𝑘subscript𝐶𝑃subscript𝑇𝑃𝜆𝐏\sigma_{k},C_{P},T_{P},\lambda(\bm{P}) be defined as above. Let Q=∑k∈𝒦qk𝑄subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑞𝑘Q=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}q_{k}. Let the stepsizes satisfy:

∑tηt=+∞,∑tln⁡(t)⋅ηt2<+∞.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝑡⋅𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{t}\eta_{t}=+\infty,\quad\sum_{t}\ln(t)\cdot\eta_{t}^{2}<+\infty. (11)

Let T𝑇T denote the total communication rounds. For T≥TP𝑇subscript𝑇𝑃T\geq T_{P}, the expected optimization error can be bounded as follows:

Theorem 2 (proof in Appendix -B) proves convergence of the expected biased objective FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B} to its minimum FB∗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}^{*} under correlated client participation. Our bound (12) captures the effect of correlation through the factor ln⁡(1/λ​(𝑷))1𝜆𝑷\ln{(1/\lambda(\bm{P}))}: a high correlation worsens the convergence rate. In particular, we found that the numerator of (12) has a quadratic-over-linear fractional dependence on 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}. Minimizing ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} leads, in general, to a different choice of 𝒒𝒒\bm{q} than minimizing ϵbiassubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}}.

III-C Minimizing the total error ϵ≤ϵopt+ϵbiasitalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon\leq{\epsilon}_{\text{opt}}+{\epsilon}_{\text{bias}}

Our analysis points out a trade-off between minimizing ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} or ϵbiassubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon_{\text{bias}}. Our goal is to find the optimal aggregation weights 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\bm{q}^{*} that minimize the upper bound on total error ϵ​(𝒒)italic-ϵ𝒒\epsilon(\bm{q}) in (10): {mini} qϵ_opt(q) + ϵ_bias(q); \addConstraintq ≥0 \addConstraint∥q∥1 = Q.

In Appendix -E we prove that (III-C) is a convex optimization problem, which can be solved with the method of Lagrange multipliers. However, the solution is not of practical utility because the constants in (10) and (12) (e.g., L𝐿L, μ𝜇\mu, ΓΓ\Gamma, CPsubscript𝐶𝑃C_{P}) are in general problem-dependent and difficult to estimate during training. In particular, ΓΓ\Gamma poses particular difficulties as it is defined in terms of the minimizer of the target objective F𝐹F, but the FL algorithm generally minimizes the biased function FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}. Moreover, the bound in (10), similarly to the bound in [32], diverges when setting some qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} equal to 00, but this is simply an artifact of the proof technique. A result of more practical interest is the following (proof in Appendix -C):

Theorem 3 (An alternative decomposition of the total error ϵitalic-ϵ{\epsilon}).

Under the same assumptions of Theorem 1, let Γ′≔maxk⁡{Fk​(𝐰B∗)−Fk∗}≔superscriptΓ′subscript𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝐵superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘\Gamma^{\prime}\coloneqq\max_{k}\{F_{k}({\bm{w}}_{B}^{*})-F_{k}^{*}\}. The following result holds:

ϵ≤2​κ2​(FB​(𝒘)−FB∗)⏟≔ϵopt+8​κ4​dT​V2​(𝜶,𝒑)​Γ′⏟≔ϵbias′,italic-ϵsubscript⏟2superscript𝜅2subscript𝐹𝐵𝒘superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵≔absentsubscriptitalic-ϵoptsubscript⏟8superscript𝜅4superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑇𝑉2𝜶𝒑superscriptΓ′≔absentsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias′\displaystyle\epsilon\leq\underbrace{2\kappa^{2}(F_{B}(\bm{w})-F_{B}^{*})}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{opt}}}+\underbrace{8\kappa^{4}d_{TV}^{2}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\Gamma^{\prime}}_{\coloneqq\epsilon_{\text{bias}}^{\prime}}, (13)

where dT​V​(𝛂,𝐩)≔12​∑k=1N|αk−pk|≔subscript𝑑𝑇𝑉𝛂𝐩12superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘d_{TV}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\coloneqq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\lvert\alpha_{k}-p_{k}\rvert is the total variation distance between the probability distributions 𝛂𝛂\bm{\alpha} and 𝐩𝐩\bm{p}.

The new constant Γ′superscriptΓ′\Gamma^{\prime} is defined in terms of 𝒘B∗superscriptsubscript𝒘𝐵\bm{w}_{B}^{*}, and then it is easier to evaluate during training. However, Γ′superscriptΓ′\Gamma^{\prime} depends on 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}, because it is evaluated at the point of minimum of FBsubscript𝐹𝐵F_{B}. This dependence makes the minimization of the right-hand side of (13) more challenging (for example, the corresponding problem is not convex). We study the minimization of the two terms ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} and ϵbias′subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′bias\epsilon^{\prime}_{\text{bias}} separately and learn some insights, which we use to design the new FL algorithm CA-Fed.

III-D Minimizing ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt{\epsilon}_{\text{{opt}}}

The minimization of ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} is still a convex optimization problem (Appendix -D). In particular, at the optimum non-negative weights are set accordingly to qk∗=a​(λ∗​πk−θ∗)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑎superscript𝜆subscript𝜋𝑘superscript𝜃q_{k}^{*}=a(\lambda^{*}\pi_{k}-\theta^{*}) with a𝑎a, λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}, and θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} positive constants (see (27)). It follows that clients with smaller availability get smaller weights in the aggregation. In particular, this suggests that clients with the smallest availability can be excluded from the aggregation, leading to the following guideline:

Guideline A: to speed up the convergence, we can exclude, i.e., set qk∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k}^{*}=0, the clients with lowest availability πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k}.

This guideline can be justified intuitively: updates from clients with low participation may be too sporadic to allow the FL algorithm to keep track of their local objectives. They act as a noise slowing down the algorithm’s convergence. It may be advantageous to exclude these clients from participating.

We observe that the choice of the aggregation weights 𝒒𝒒\bm{q} does not affect the clients’ availability process and, in particular, λ​(𝑷)𝜆𝑷\lambda(\bm{P}). However, if the algorithm excludes some clients, it is possible to consider the state space of the Markov chain that only specifies the availability state of the remaining clients, and this Markov chain may have different spectral properties. For the sake of concreteness, we consider here (and in the rest of the paper) the particular case when the availability of each client k𝑘k evolves according to a two-states Markov chain (Atk)t≥0subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑘𝑡0(A_{t}^{k})_{t\geq 0} with transition probability matrix 𝑷𝒌subscript𝑷𝒌\bm{P_{k}} and these Markov chains are all independent. In this case, the aggregate process is described by the product Markov chain (At)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0} with transition matrix 𝑷=⨂k∈𝒦𝑷𝒌𝑷subscripttensor-product𝑘𝒦subscript𝑷𝒌\bm{P}=\bigotimes_{\scriptstyle k\in\mathcal{K}}\bm{P_{k}} and λ​(𝑷)=maxk∈𝒦⁡λ​(𝑷𝒌)𝜆𝑷subscript𝑘𝒦𝜆subscript𝑷𝒌\lambda(\bm{P})=\max_{\scriptstyle k\in\mathcal{K}}\lambda(\bm{P_{k}}), where 𝑷𝒊​⨂𝑷𝒋subscript𝑷𝒊tensor-productsubscript𝑷𝒋\bm{P_{i}}\bigotimes\bm{P_{j}} denotes the Kronecker product between matrices 𝑷𝒊subscript𝑷𝒊\bm{P_{i}} and 𝑷𝒋subscript𝑷𝒋\bm{P_{j}} [30, Exercise 12.6]. In this setting, it is possible to redefine the Markov chain (At)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝐴𝑡𝑡0(A_{t})_{t\geq 0} by taking into account the reduced state space defined by the clients with a non-null aggregation weight, i.e., 𝑷′=⨂k′∈𝒦​|qk′>​0𝑷𝒌′superscript𝑷bold-′subscripttensor-productsuperscript𝑘′𝒦ketsubscript𝑞superscript𝑘′0subscript𝑷superscript𝒌bold-′\bm{P^{\prime}}=\bigotimes_{\scriptstyle k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}|q_{k^{\prime}}>0}\bm{P_{k^{\prime}}} and λ​(𝑷′)=maxk′∈𝒦​|qk′>​0⁡λ​(𝑷𝒌′)𝜆superscript𝑷bold-′subscriptsuperscript𝑘′𝒦ketsubscript𝑞superscript𝑘′0𝜆subscript𝑷superscript𝒌bold-′\lambda(\bm{P^{\prime}})=\max_{\scriptstyle k^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}|q_{k^{\prime}}>0}\lambda(\bm{P_{k^{\prime}}}), which is potentially smaller than the case when all clients participate to the aggregation. These considerations lead to the following guideline:

Guideline B: to speed up the convergence, we can exclude, i.e., set qk∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k}^{*}=0, the clients with largest λ​(𝐏𝐤)𝜆subscript𝐏𝐤\lambda(\bm{P_{k}}).

Intuition also supports this guideline. Clients with large λ​(𝑷𝒌)𝜆subscript𝑷𝒌\lambda(\bm{P_{k}}) tend to be available or unavailable for long periods of time. Due to the well-known catastrophic forgetting problem affecting gradient methods [33, 34], these clients may unfairly steer the algorithm toward their local objective when they appear at the final stages of the training period. Moreover, their participation in the early stages may be useless, as their contribution will be forgotten during their long absence. The FL algorithm may benefit from directly neglecting such clients.

We observe that guideline B strictly applies to this specific setting where clients’ dynamics are independent (and there is no spatial correlation). We do not provide a corresponding guideline for the case when clients are spatially correlated (we leave this task for future research). However, in this more general setting, it is possible to ignore guideline B but still draw on guidelines A and C, or still consider guideline B if clients are spatially correlated (see discussion in Section VI-B).

III-E Minimizing ϵbias′superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias′{\epsilon}_{\text{{bias}}}^{\prime}

The bias error ϵbias′subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′bias\epsilon^{\prime}_{\text{bias}} in  (13) vanishes when the total variation distance between the target importance 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} and the biased importance 𝒑𝒑\bm{p} is zero, i.e., when qk∝αk/πk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦q_{k}\propto\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Then, after excluding the clients that contribute the most to the optimization error and particularly slow down the convergence (guidelines A and B), we can assign to the remaining clients an aggregation weight inversely proportional to their availability, such that the bias error ϵbias′superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias′{\epsilon}_{\text{{bias}}}^{\prime} is minimized.

Guideline C: to reduce the bias error, we set qk∗∝αk/πkproportional-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘q_{k}^{*}\propto\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k} for the clients that are not excluded by the previous guidelines.

IV Proposed Algorithm

Guidelines A and B in Section III suggest that the minimization of ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} can lead to the exclusion of some available clients from the aggregation step (3), in particular those with low availability and/or high correlation. For the remaining clients, guideline C proposes to set their aggregation weight inversely proportional to their availability to reduce the bias error ϵbias′superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias′\epsilon_{\text{bias}}^{\prime}. Motivated by these insights, we propose CA-Fed, a client sampling and aggregation strategy that takes into account the problem of correlated client availability in FL, described in Algorithm 1. CA-Fed learns during training which are the clients to exclude and how to set the aggregation weights of the other clients to achieve a good trade-off between ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵopt\epsilon_{\text{opt}} and ϵbias′superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias′\epsilon_{\text{bias}}^{\prime}. While guidelines A and B indicate which clients to remove, the exact number of clients to remove at round t𝑡t is identified by minimizing ϵ(t)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon^{(t)} as a proxy for the bound in (13):444 Following (13), one could reasonably introduce a hyper-parameter to weigh the relative importance of the optimization and bias terms in the sum. We discuss this additional optimization of CA-Fed in Section VI-A.

ϵ(t)≔FB​(𝒘t,0)−FB∗+dT​V2​(𝜶,𝒑)​Γ′.≔superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡subscript𝐹𝐵subscript𝒘𝑡0superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑇𝑉2𝜶𝒑superscriptΓ′\displaystyle{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}{\epsilon}^{(t)}}\coloneqq F_{B}(\bm{w}_{t,0}){\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}-F_{B}^{*}}+d_{TV}^{2}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\Gamma^{\prime}. (14)

IV-A CA-Fed’s core steps

At each communication round t𝑡t, the server sends the current model 𝒘t,0subscript𝒘𝑡0\bm{w}_{t,0} to all active clients and each client k𝑘k sends back a noisy estimate Fk(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑡𝑘F^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}_{k} of the current loss computed on a batch of samples ℬt,0ksuperscriptsubscriptℬ𝑡0𝑘\mathcal{B}_{t,0}^{k}, i.e., Fk(t)=1|ℬt,0k|​∑ξ∈ℬt,0kf​(𝒘t,0,ξ)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑡𝑘1superscriptsubscriptℬ𝑡0𝑘subscript𝜉superscriptsubscriptℬ𝑡0𝑘𝑓subscript𝒘𝑡0𝜉F^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}_{k}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_{t,0}^{k}|}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}_{t,0}^{k}}f(\bm{w}_{t,0},\xi) (line 1). The server uses these values and the information about the current set of available clients Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t} to refine its own estimates of each client’s loss (𝑭^(t)=(F^k(t))k∈𝒦superscript^𝑭𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝐹𝑘𝑡𝑘𝒦\hat{\bm{F}}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}=(\hat{F}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)})_{k\in\mathcal{K}}), and each client’s loss minimum value (𝑭^∗=(F^k∗)k∈𝒦superscript^𝑭subscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝐹𝑘𝑘𝒦\hat{\bm{F}}^{*}=(\hat{F}_{k}^{*})_{k\in\mathcal{K}}), as well as of Γ′superscriptΓ′\Gamma^{\prime}, πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k}, λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k}, and ϵ(t)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, denoted as Γ^(t)′\hat{{\Gamma}}^{{}^{\prime}\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, π^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜋𝑘𝑡\hat{\pi}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, λ^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜆𝑘𝑡\hat{\lambda}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, and ϵ^(t)superscript^italic-ϵ𝑡\hat{\epsilon}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, respectively (possible estimators are described below) (line 1).

The server decides whether excluding clients whose availability pattern exhibits high correlation (high λ^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜆𝑘𝑡\hat{\lambda}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}) (line 1). First, the server considers all clients in descending order of 𝝀^(t)superscript^𝝀𝑡\hat{\bm{\lambda}}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)} (line 1), and evaluates if, by excluding them (line 1), ϵ^(t)superscript^italic-ϵ𝑡\hat{\epsilon}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)} appears to be decreasing by more than a threshold τ≥0𝜏0\tau\geq 0 (line 1). Then, the server considers clients in ascending order of 𝝅^(t)superscript^𝝅𝑡\hat{\bm{\pi}}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, and repeats the same procedure to possibly exclude some of the clients with low availability (low π^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜋𝑘𝑡\hat{\pi}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}) (lines 1).

Once the participating clients (those with qk>0subscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k}>0) have been selected, the server notifies them to proceed updating the current models (lines 1–1) according to (2), while the other available clients stay idle. Finally, model’s updates are aggregated according to (3) (line 1).

For π^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜋𝑘𝑡\hat{\pi}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, the server can simply keep track of the total number of times client k𝑘k was available up to time t𝑡t and compute π^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜋𝑘𝑡\hat{\pi}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)} using a Bayesian estimator with beta prior, i.e., π^k(t)=(∑s≤t𝟙k∈As+nk)/(t+nk+mk)superscriptsubscript^𝜋𝑘𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡subscript1𝑘subscript𝐴𝑠subscript𝑛𝑘𝑡subscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘\hat{\pi}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}=(\sum_{s\leq t}\mathds{1}_{k\in A_{s}}+n_{k})/(t+n_{k}+m_{k}), where nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k} and mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} are the initial parameters of the beta prior.

For λ^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜆𝑘𝑡\hat{\lambda}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}, the server can assume the client’s availability evolves according to a Markov chain with two states (available and unavailable), track the corresponding number of state transitions, and estimate the transition matrix 𝑷^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝑷𝑘𝑡\hat{\bm{P}}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)} through a Bayesian estimator similarly to what done for π^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜋𝑘𝑡\hat{\pi}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}. Finally, λ^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝜆𝑘𝑡\hat{\lambda}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)} is obtained computing the eigenvalues of 𝑷^k(t)superscriptsubscript^𝑷𝑘𝑡\hat{\bm{P}}_{k}^{\scriptscriptstyle(t)}.

IV-C CA-Fed’s computation/communication cost

CA-Fed aims to improve training convergence and not to reduce its computation and communication overhead. Nevertheless, excluding some available clients reduces the overall training cost, as we will discuss in this section referring, for the sake of concreteness, to neural networks’ training.

The available clients not selected for training are only requested to evaluate their local loss on the current model once on a single batch instead than performing E𝐸E gradient updates, which would require roughly 2×E−12𝐸12\times E-1 more calculations (because of the forward and backward pass). For the selected clients, there is no extra computation cost as computing the loss corresponds to the forward pass they should, in any case, perform during the first local gradient update.

In terms of communication, the excluded clients only transmit the loss, a single scalar, much smaller than the model update. Conversely, participating clients transmit the local loss and the model update. Still, this additional overhead is negligible and likely fully compensated by the communication savings for the excluded clients.

V Experimental Evaluation

V-A Experimental Setup

Federated system simulator

In our experiments, we simulate the clients’ availability dynamics featuring different levels of temporal correlations. We model the activity of each client as a two-state homogeneous Markov process with state space 𝒮={“active”,“inactive”}𝒮“active”“inactive”\mathcal{S}=\{\text{``\emph{active}''},\text{``\emph{inactive}''}\}. We use pk,ssubscript𝑝𝑘𝑠p_{k,s} to denote the probability that client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} remains in state s∈𝒮𝑠𝒮s\in\mathcal{S}.

In order to simulate the statistical heterogeneity present in the federated learning system, we consider an experimental setting with two disjoint groups of clients Gi,i=1,2formulae-sequencesubscript𝐺𝑖𝑖12{G}_{i},~{}i=1,2, to which we associate two different data distributions 𝒫i,i=1,2formulae-sequencesubscript𝒫𝑖𝑖12\mathcal{P}_{i},~{}i=1,2, to be precised later. Let ri=|Gi|/N,i=1,2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖𝑁𝑖12r_{i}=|{G}_{i}|/N,~{}i=1,2 denote the fraction of clients in group i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2. In order to simulate the heterogeneity of clients’ availability patterns in realistic federated systems, we split the clients of each group in two classes uniformly at random: “more available” clients whose steady-state probability to be active is πk,active=1/2+gsubscript𝜋𝑘active12𝑔{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\pi_{k,\text{active}}}=1/2+g and “less available” clients with πk,active=1/2−gsubscript𝜋𝑘active12𝑔{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\pi_{k,\text{active}}}=1/2-g, where g∈(0,1/2)𝑔012g\in(0,1/2) is a parameter controlling the heterogeneity of clients availability. We furthermore split each class of clients in two sub-classes uniformly at random: “correlated” clients that tend to persist in the same state (λk=νsubscript𝜆𝑘𝜈{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\lambda_{k}}=\nu with values of ν𝜈\nu close to 111), and “weakly correlated” clients that are almost as likely to keep as to change their state (λk∼𝒩​(0,ε2)similar-tosubscript𝜆𝑘𝒩0superscript𝜀2{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\lambda_{k}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\varepsilon^{2}), with ε𝜀\varepsilon close to 00). In our experiments, we suppose that r1=r2=1/2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟212r_{1}=r_{2}=1/2, g=0.4𝑔0.4g=0.4, ν=0.9𝜈0.9\nu=0.9, and ε=10−2𝜀superscript102\varepsilon=10^{-2}.

Datasets and models

All experiments are performed on a binary classification synthetic dataset (described in Appendix -F) and on the real-world MNIST dataset [35], using N=24𝑁24N=24 clients. For MNIST dataset, we introduce statistical heterogeneity across the two groups of clients (i.e., we make the two distributions 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} different), following the same approach in [36]: 1) every client is assigned a random subset of the total training data; 2) the data of clients from the second group is modified by randomly swapping two pairs of labels. We maintain the original training/test data split of MNIST and use 20%percent2020\% of the training dataset as validation dataset. We use a linear classifier with a ridge penalization of parameter 10−2superscript10210^{-2}, which is a strongly convex objective function, for both the synthetic and the real-world MNIST datasets.

Benchmarks

We compare CA-Fed, defined in Algorithm 1, with the Unbiased aggregation strategy, where all the active clients participate and receive a weight inversely proportional to their availability, and with the state-of-the-art FL algorithms discussed in Section II: F3AST [18] and AdaFed [19]. We tuned the learning rates η,ηs𝜂subscript𝜂𝑠\eta,~{}\eta_{s} via grid search, on the grid η:{10−3,10−2.5,10−2,10−1.5,10−1}:𝜂superscript103superscript102.5superscript102superscript101.5superscript101\eta:\{10^{-3},10^{-2.5},10^{-2},10^{-1.5},10^{-1}\}, ηs:{10−2,10−1.5,10−1,10−0.5,100}:subscript𝜂𝑠superscript102superscript101.5superscript101superscript100.5superscript100\eta_{s}:\{10^{-2},10^{-1.5},10^{-1},10^{-0.5},10^{0}\}. For CA-Fed, we used τ=0𝜏0\tau=0, β=0.2𝛽0.2\beta=0.2. We assume all algorithms can access an oracle providing the true availability parameters for each client. In practice, Unbiased, AdaFed, and F3AST rely on the exact knowledge of πk,activesubscript𝜋𝑘active{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\pi_{k,\text{active}}}, and CA-Fed on πk,activesubscript𝜋𝑘active{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\pi_{k,\text{active}}} and λksubscript𝜆𝑘{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\lambda_{k}}. 555 The authors have provided public access to their code and data at:
     https://github.com/arodio/CA-Fed.

V-B Experimental Results

Figure 1 shows the availability of each client during a training run on the synthetic dataset. Clients selected (resp. excluded) by CA-Fed are highlighted in black (resp. red). We observe that excluded clients tend to be those with low average availability or high correlation.

Figure 2 shows the importance pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} (averaged over time) given by different algorithms to each client k𝑘k during a full training run. We observe that all the algorithms, except Unbiased, depart from the target importance 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha}. As suggested by guidelines A and B, CA-Fed tends to favor the group of “more available” clients, at the expense of the “less available” clients.

Figure 3 shows the time-average accuracy up to round t𝑡t of the learned model averaged over three different runs. On both datasets, CA-Fed achieves the highest accuracy, which is about a percentage point higher than the second best algorithm (F3AST). Table I shows for each algorithm: the average over three runs of the maximum test accuracy achieved during training, the time-average test accuracy achieved during training, together with its standard deviation within the second half of the training period. Results show that while CA-Fed achieves a maximum accuracy which is comparable to the Unbiased baseline and state-of-the-art AdaFed and F3AST, it gets a higher time-average accuracy (1.241.241.24 percentage points) in comparison to the second best (F3AST), and a smaller standard deviation (1.5×1.5\times) in comparison to the second best (F3AST).

VI Discussion

In this section, we discuss some general concerns and remarks on our algorithm.

VI-A Controlling the number of excluded clients

Theorems 1 and 3 suggest that the condition number κ2superscript𝜅2\kappa^{2} can play a meaningful role in the minimization of the total error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Our algorithm uses a proxy (ϵ(t)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon^{(t)}) of the total error. To take into account the effect of κ2superscript𝜅2\kappa^{2}, we can introduce a hyper-parameter that weights the relative importance of the optimization and bias error in (14):

ϵ′(t)≔FB​(𝒘t,0)−FB∗+κ¯2⋅dT​V2​(𝜶,𝒑)​Γ′.≔superscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑡subscript𝐹𝐵subscript𝒘𝑡0superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵⋅superscript¯𝜅2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑇𝑉2𝜶𝒑superscriptΓ′{\epsilon^{\prime}}^{(t)}\coloneqq F_{B}(\bm{w}_{t,0})-F_{B}^{*}+\bar{\kappa}^{2}\cdot d_{TV}^{2}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{p})\Gamma^{\prime}.

A small value of κ¯2superscript¯𝜅2\bar{\kappa}^{2} penalizes the bias term in favor of the optimization error, resulting in a larger number of clients excluded by CA-Fed. On the other hand, CA-Fed tends to include more clients for a large value of κ¯2superscript¯𝜅2\bar{\kappa}^{2}. Asymptotically, for κ¯2→+∞→superscript¯𝜅2\bar{\kappa}^{2}\rightarrow+\infty, CA-Fed reduces to the Unbiased baseline. To further improve the performance of CA-Fed, a finer tuning of the values of κ¯2superscript¯𝜅2\bar{\kappa}^{2} can be performed.

VI-B CA-Fed in presence of spatial correlation

Although CA-Fed is mainly designed to handle temporal correlation, it does not necessarily perform poorly in presence of spatial correlation, as well.

Consider the following spatially-correlated scenario: clients are grouped in clusters, each cluster c∈𝒞𝑐𝒞c\in\mathcal{C} is characterized by an underlying Markov chain, which determines when all clients in the cluster are available/unavailable, the Markov chains of different clusters are independent. Let λcsubscript𝜆𝑐\lambda_{c} denote the second largest eigenvalue in module of cluster-c𝑐c’s Markov chain. In this case, one needs to exclude all clients in the cluster c¯=arg⁡maxc∈𝒞⁡λc¯𝑐subscript𝑐𝒞subscript𝜆𝑐\bar{c}=\arg\max_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\lambda_{c} to reduce the eigenvalue of the aggregate Markov chain.

In this setting, CA-Fed would associate similar eigenvalue estimates to all clients in the same cluster, then it would correctly start considering for exclusion the clients in cluster c¯¯𝑐\bar{c} and potentially remove sequentially all clients in the same cluster. These considerations suggest that CA-Fed may still operate correctly even in presence of spatial correlation.

VI-C About CA-Fed’s fairness

A strategy that excludes clients from the training phase, such as CA-Fed, may naturally raise fairness concerns. The concept of fairness in FL does not have a unified definition in the literature [37, Chapter 8]: fairness goals can be captured by a suitable choice of the target weights in (1). For example, per-client fairness can be achieved by setting αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} equal for every client, while per-sample fairness by setting αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} proportional to the local dataset size |Dk|subscript𝐷𝑘|D_{k}|. If we assume that the global objective in (1) indeed reflects also fairness concerns, then CA-Fed is intrinsically fair, in the sense that it guarantees that the performance objective of the learned model is as close as possible to its minimum value.

VII Conclusion

This paper presented the first convergence analysis for a FedAvg-like FL algorithm under heterogeneous and correlated client availability. The analysis quantifies how correlation adversely affects the algorithm’s convergence rate and highlights a general bias-versus-convergence-speed trade-off. Guided by the theoretical analysis, we proposed CA-Fed, a new FL algorithm that tries to balance the conflicting goals of maximizing convergence speed and minimizing model bias. Our experimental results demonstrate that adaptively excluding clients with high temporal correlation and low availability is an effective approach to handle the heterogeneous and correlated client availability in FL.

-A Proof of Theorem 1

We bound the optimization error of the target objective as the optimization error of the biased objective plus a bias term:

-C Proof of Theorem 3

-E Convexity of ϵopt+ϵbiassubscriptitalic-ϵoptsubscriptitalic-ϵbias\epsilon_{\text{opt}}+\epsilon_{\text{bias}}

-F Synthetic dataset

Our synthetic datasets has been generated as follows:

  1. 1.

    For client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, sample group identity iksubscript𝑖𝑘i_{k} from a Bernoulli distribution of parameter 1/2121/2;

    For client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and sample index j∈{1,…,150}𝑗1…150j\in\{1,\dots,150\}, sample clients input data 𝒙k(j)∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑗𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑\bm{x}_{k}^{(j)}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}) from the d𝑑d-dimensional normal distribution;

  4. 4.

    For client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} such that ik=0subscript𝑖𝑘0i_{k}=0 and sample index j∈{1,…,150}𝑗1…150j\in\{1,\dots,150\}, sample the true labels yk(j)superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑗y_{k}^{(j)} from a Bernoulli distribution with parameter equal to sigmoid​(⟨𝒘∗,𝒙k(j)⟩)sigmoidsuperscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑗\text{sigmoid}(\langle\bm{w}^{*},\bm{x}_{k}^{(j)}\rangle);
